The goal is to provide Accessible options for content developers. Any thoughts, or alternative ideas?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: TinyMCE - Selecting a colour palate
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, We've disabled this in the core Moodle product for a number of reasons and you should be aware of these before re-enabling them. Firstly the issue you touch upon, accessibity. Colour is often, incorrectly, used to convey meaning. The old 'Green means good, red means bad'. That may be fine for a lot of users, but it's a problem for many. In the example syou give (key concepts, case studies, reflection, deadlines, warnings)... these are all conveying an important concept and colour alone should not be used for this. The other main issue is that of fitting in with themes. Again, you touch on this, but the problem is more involved. Whilst you can probably find a set of colours which fit with your current theme with _relative_ ease, TinyMCE stores colours as hex in style attributes on the element itself. Should your organisation ever change their theme, their colour palette, or even just allow users to select a different theme (e.g. for accessibility resaons), the colours will nto change and cannot be easily changed in line with the theme without modifying the content further.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: TinyMCE - Selecting a colour palate

ResponsesInList.Title: Security issues (like, fairly extreme?)
ResponsesInList.Text: In the spirit of GNU, openness, and Free S/W, I want to bring up another issue that I don't know how it works: This is written in PHP--you can put PHP code in it (just type <?PHP...), why doesn't the (malicious) PHP code execute causing havoc all over the system?  Is it because it uses an RDBMS?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Security issues (like, fairly extreme?)
ResponsesInList.Text: You will have to give more context to your question. You appear to be assuming that any php code entered by any client in a formform will be executed on the server .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Security issues (like, fairly extreme?)
ResponsesInList.Text: In PHP the editor-supplied data is a post variable such as $_POST["html_edit_data_string"] (are the quotes necessary?).  That string is stored as an HTML page somewhere, and then that page is loaded by a user/client. When it is loaded, any php that is in the page gets executed by the server on its way to the browser.  To prevent that, the string has to go through regular expression filters to take out malisous code that would execute on the server (PHP has all the system calls (such as "rm" any files created by the Apache user--which your ID when you get executed).   Likewise, javascript could be executed by the browser, though I only think it can only set/earse cookies.. but it could be AJAX code that... This is interesting to me for a whole other reason-this is where the image data (string w/in a string) can be located, altered into a normal image (ie jpg) and stored, and the img reference to it can can be subsituted into the string to string to create a normal web page, rather than one w/ image data in it (there is really no other way). I wrote my very last paper using the original "composer" that came with ncsa moasic (first graphic browswer), later netscape, etc, to Sea Monkey.  I am wondering if that is not the place to develop given all potential the security issues. Sea Monkey composer has problems, but all are with optional features that can be found in the browser itself, such as text searching and spell checking.  The major advantage is that I could paste from the clipboard, such as illustrations, or, even more useful, text directly from google books so that I could look at it while I wrote-in the material for the paper(s). I will continue with the TinyMCE browser until it has a filesystem list for all the files and a search function, then give it a rest.  I am beginning to feel that the web-connecting "app" route (such as on Android) makes more sense than the "intelligent" web page that started as CGI and became javascript.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Security issues (like, fairly extreme?)
ResponsesInList.Text: " When it is loaded, any php that is in the page gets executed by the server on its way to the browser." No, it doesn't.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Security issues (like, fairly extreme?)
ResponsesInList.Text: There are various layers of defense against this: (notheing to do with using a relational database ). All input is filtered, to remove obviously nasty stuff. (e.g. <script> tags.) Use input is handled as strings. That is, we do code like echo $userinput; we don't do code like eval($userinpus); But acutally, we do more than that. More filtering and escaping is done during output. This is all pretty standard stuff when it comes to creating web applications. There is more at http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Security .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Security issues (like, fairly extreme?)
ResponsesInList.Text: that doc says: "Use the XMLDB library. This takes care of most escaping issues for you." Another doc says " XMLDB is Moodle's database abstraction layer " Sounds pretty relational to me...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Security issues (like, fairly extreme?)
ResponsesInList.Text: There are different types of escaping, to deal with different sorts of potential security vulerabilities. XMLDB does the escaping necessary to prevent SQL -injection attacks. Until now in this thread, you have been talking about other sorts of vulnerabilites, not SQL-injection.

ResponsesInList.Title: Plugins for Atto editor: Create new or edit existing?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, My question has more to do with 'best-practice' approach of creating plugins for Atto, and not so much a technical query. I use an example below, but I'm more interested in discussing the best overall approach , and not in finding a solution to this particular case. Use Case: We need to be able to set the colour of font to predefined brand-specific colours. However the generic FontColor plugin, that ships with Atto, has only a few select colors to choose from (not the exact colours we want). My question: should we create a new plugin, that mimics the functionality of the existing FontColor plugin exactly, the only exception being the colors it makes available? Or should we edit the existing FontColor plugin to offer our brand-specific colours? I prefer the original approach as we then dont have to fiddle with the FontColor plugin at all, and therefore benefit from any code maintenance to that plugin moving forward. The downside being that the additional button in our toolbar is going to clutter the editor, and will suck up more of my dev time. The lazy developer in me points out that it would take only a few small changes (and not much time) to edit the plugin and make the new colours available. As soon as I use the word from I get a 404 error. ____________________________________ We already discussed the features to look for when you are looking for web hosting, but I'm going to give you some advice in selecting a web host . I'm going to introduce you to 3 categories of web hosting that I've totally made up - Cheap, Great, and Extreme Cheap web hosting The price range for cheap web hosting is usually 5 to 10 dollars a month. It may seem strange, but the cheap web hosting plans are usually the plans that offer the most. Some careful shopping will get you a cheap web hosting package that has unlimited disk space, unlimited bandwidth, unlimited my sql databases, Fantastico and lets you host unlimited web sites. This is the type of web hosting I highly recommend to anybody who is setting up their first web site, for many reasons. First it is cheap so you're not spending a fortune while you are learning, second because once you have your first web site, it's trivial to set up a second, third fourth and more - your only cost is domain name registration. You may be asking how these companies offer such a great service at such a low price, and the answer is that they oversell http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overselling#Web_Hosting their capacity. When you sign up for web hosting, even though it looks like you are on your own server you are actually sharing a physical server with many other customers. The cheaper web hosting companies put more users on one server than the server is able to support, assuming that most users won't use their account to it's fullest capacity. This brings us to the drawbacks of using cheap web hosting. If one of your neighbours starts mis-behaving, your web site will get slow, or possibly be unavailable (although this kind of problem is usually dealt with quickly). There are also other, hidden limits (like inode limits or cpu usage limits), so if your web site starts to get popular/busy you will need to move it to a dedicated server. This also means if you have a sudden spike in traffic, your web site might be temporarily disabled. Even with the drawbacks, I highly recommend using a cheap web host for your first web site, because it is so flexible and cheap, and it will be a while (if ever) before you need to move to a 'great' web host. Great web hosting This is the next step up from cheap web hosting and generally costs $15 - $100 a month (Excellent companies can be found for $15 - 20). Web hosts in this class normally do not offer unlimited anything. For example, the basic Liquidweb hosting plan gives you 1GB of disk space, and 120GB of data transfer a month for $15. The difference is they do not oversell their capacity (or they oversell less) so you will get better web site performance, less downtime, and less chance of a traffic spike causing problems (as long as you stay within your bandwidth limit). The other nice thing about using a great web host is that usually the tech support is much better. When you request technical support from Liquidweb you normally get an answer within 30 minutes, and there is an actual 1800 number that you can call and talk to a person. I recommend great web hosting if you only plan on hosting one web site, or if you are building a business web site that need to be rock solid and fast, all of the time. Extreme web hosting You will know when you need extreme web hosting. When you get into hundreds of thousands of visits a month, and your hosting provider is constantly calling you, it's probably time to upgrade. With extreme web hosting (properly called dedicated server or co-location) you rent or buy a server or servers. The cost starts at 100 dollars a month and goes up very quickly. Usually it's up to you to manage the servers, but of course you can pay to have the company manage them for you. If you get to this point you will need at least one IT person, if not a whole IT team to manage your site - this is not something you want to do alone. It is highly unlikely that anybody would need to start out with a dedicated server.

```text
        $editor_toolbar = <<<EOT
```

```text
--- a/lib/form/editor.php

         // Note: for some reason the code using this setting does not like bools.


         $this->_options['subdirs'] = (int)($this->_options['subdirs'] == 1);


 


+        // Atto toolbar options.


+        if (!empty($options['atto:toolbar'])) {


+            $this->_options['atto:toolbar'] = $options['atto:toolbar'];


+        }


+

```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Use wwwroot variable in ATTO
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Matheus, The short answer is no , and we will not accept any change which introduces such a 'feature'. The wwwroot variable is used to ensure that there is one, authoritative, URL for the site. Moodle has a number of places which expect that you are accessing it via the correct address. If you are not then you will likely enter a number of weird issues such as this one. Additionally you'll see that if you don't use the correct address the files you have uploaded will be removed after approximately 4 days because they will not have been picked up by the file processor when parsing the text, and they will therefore not be moved from the draft files area. If you really want to use the internal IP address, then I suggest you set the IP in your local host file. Something like https://www.howtogeek.com/howto/27350/beginner-geek-how-to-edit-your-hosts-file/ will help you find out how to do so. Andrew

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: tinyMCE converts relative urls to absolute
ResponsesInList.Text: Your server may require two different IP address when accessed from the public internet, and when accessed from your own network, but if so, there is no reason to expose users to that implementation detail. On the internet, there is a system (DNS) for converting symbolic names like my.moodle.site to the appropriate IP address. On your internal network there will be some way of resolving nice human-readable names like my.moodle.site into the correct IP address (or other routing address). What you should do is use the same nice human-readable name like my.moodle.site (or whatever your domain name is) on both sides of the network. I did not suggest that you route internal users via the internet.

ResponsesInList.Title: What stopps sites switching to TinyMCE as default
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, In a german forum of Moodle in higher education we recently a thread with the question about the experiences from moving to TinyMCE as the default editor. What keeps sites away from moving to Tiny at the moment? One note beforehand, in recent Moodle versions fixes and improvments were done in the TinyMCE intregration. Not all of the issues mentioned below are from Moodle 4.3. Some of the things might be resolved already in the current 4.4 release. I will here try to list various aspects and obstacles that were mentioned when the TinyMCE was in use. I just comment here without having this verified. Some of the reports are also a bit unspecific. Missing broader formatting options (other font sizes etc...) Missing plugins to format/insert object (e.g. Embeded question, Teams Link) that exist in Atto Links were inserted but mysteriously had been moved to the begining of the text/paragraph. Stripping certain tags or attributes that are otherwise usable ( MDL-80953 , MDL-76233 because I was involded there I mention these two explicitly). There are a bunch of institutions including the one where I am working at, that did not report much problems. If so, these could be solved with an additional plugin or other fix. For the worst case we recommend switch back to Atto or even use plain text. Also what is considerable from my experience: technical departments such as math, physics, chemistry, computer sciense tend to use more technical annotations (Tex, source code, chemistry formulas) that cause problems when edited with the TinyMCE. This is a filter that lists issues in the TinyMCE component that are open or in development: https://tracker.moodle.org/issues/?filter=25025 For all that are afrait of loosing functionality: If something is not working as excpected please check, who is involved (teachers only or all users). When teachers only, how big is the group? Is there a chance to provide them with a feasible workaround? In our institution the computer sience department faces the most problems but these people are also the most skilled ones. HTH in the development and in migration stategies. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Relative Linking within Moodle using the HTML Editor
ResponsesInList.Text: At Swansea College, all our systems use a SSO (using LDAP ).  This means that on our Moodle installation we require both an internal http://swanvle/moodle plus a https://vle.swancoll.ac.uk .  We have set Moodle up to distinguish which route access is made and defines the $CFG-> wwwroot variable in config.php as required. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thanks Chris Simpson

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Relative Linking within Moodle using the HTML Editor
ResponsesInList.Text: Dirty fix idea. Hack a filter to check current domain and change link accordingly. e.g. If domain is https://vle.swancoll.ac.uk the filter rewrites the domain of any http://swanvle/moodle links to https://vle.swancoll.ac.uk . I got the Catalyst IT team to do something similar for us to automatically add an ezproxy prefix to links to research databases like ProQuest or Ebsco.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Relative Linking within Moodle using the HTML Editor
ResponsesInList.Text: I have already added similar code to the config.php file to set the cfg->wwwroot. Do you know which file(s) and which function(s) needs to be altered for your suggested fix?  Your suggestion sounds great! Many thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Relative Linking within Moodle using the HTML Editor
ResponsesInList.Text: Copy, paste and rename an existing filter folder like censor or activitynames as a starting point. You'll need to know some php & reg expressions to get the specifics - sorry can't be much help there. Have attached the original hacked filter I got an IT tutor to do for me. We've since moved onto a more advanced solution but the principles should be similar to your requirements. The filter has the following logic: Check for urls Check if the URL already has the the ezproxy prefix Loop thru the text checking for the defined domains and adding the ezproxy prefix where necessary Array of domains we are interested in Identify URLs with expired ezproxy domains (foundincorrect) Substitute a correct domain for the incorrect one (changeincorrect)

ResponsesInList.Title: table background image disappearing? - check case in path!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello I just spent some time finding out why a table background image could not be displayed in a cloze question, and also in a general document - although it was displayed initially in the editor. The answer is simple: The editor changes uppercase letters in the file paths of the style-attribute when it parses the table-code. Case sensitive servers will then not find the image anymore. I removed the uppercase letters from the directory where the images are located and voilà: table-background works! I didn't know where else to post this bug, so if someone else know a better place, please forward! Cheers Urs, ETH Zürich, Switzerland

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: TinyMCE 6 in Moodle 4.1.4
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andrew, Thanks for your reply. Maybe all of this comes down to how well the features of the TinyMCE 6 plugins have been described: Accessibility checker According to Moodle Docs ( https://docs.moodle.org/401/en/TinyMCE_editor#Accessibility_checker ), the following issues should be checked and reported: Images with empty or no ALT text --> We found that images with alt="" are skipped, but images without the alt="" and/or role="presentation" do get noticed. Long text without proper headings gets noticed, but as soon as you'd add a few headers at the bottom of this, the 'long text, please break up with headings' notice disappears. Table issues don't get reported, at least not the way I built one: A table created in TinyMCE doesn't get reported (instead it breaks the entire report even if there are issues elsewhere in the text). Then I added an MS Word created table (3 rows, 4 columns, no data, no captions or column headers, 2 cells merged), and got a whole bunch of information. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: TinyMCE 6 in Moodle 4.1.4
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost, Is there a setting we can manipulate to get autosave to work with TinyMCE 6? I went about writing some text in a mod_page that was previously saved, then quit the page using the cancel button, and returned afterwards: my last additions weren't saved, so the expected autosave version of the page wasn't restored. You'd expect a warning 'Leaving this page without saving', and a notice 'A previous version of this text has been restored'. This does work out of the box and there is no configuration required. The autosave will push changes every time TinyMCE create an undo point - that's typically whenever you press the [return] key, change focus, etc. The issue here is that by pressing the "Cancel" button you are clearing the form content and resetting all state. When that happens we deliberately clear the autosave content as we've done for many years with our previous editors. If you just refresh the page, then you will get both the form change detetion, and the editor autosave. We have no idea what this plugin actually does, so we checked the TinyMCE documentation on what we thought was the same plugin. What does this plugin do? Does it handle all the Moodle filter features? Or something else. In any case, documentation on this seems to be missing. This is a Moodle plugin, not the native TinyMCE plugin. It is purely used to create a link to either an external website, a Moodle page, or some content, within your text. It integrates with the Moodle repository plugin to allow you to search for, and insert, some Moodle-specific content. It also provides you with an interface to configure some additional options such as setting the link text (instead of using the URL ), and opening the link in a new window. Regarding the accessibility questions: Images with empty or no ALT text --> We found that images with alt="" are skipped, but images without the alt="" and/or role="presentation" do get noticed. This is a valid case and the documented approach for decorative images per the W3C Accessibility Initiative , who specifically note: In these cases, a null (empty) alt text should be provided (alt="") so that they can be ignored by assistive technologies, such as screen readers. Text values for these types of images would add audible clutter to screen reader output or could distract users if the topic is different from that in adjacent text. Leaving out the alt attribute is also not an option because when it is not provided, some screen readers will announce the file name of the image instead. This is therefore a correct behaviour. Long text without proper headings gets noticed, but as soon as you'd add a few headers at the bottom of this, the 'long text, please break up with headings' notice disappears. I'm sure we can improve this detection. I'd suggest raising an issue in the Moodle Tracker to improve this. Table issues don't get reported, at least not the way I built one: A table created in TinyMCE doesn't get reported (instead it breaks the entire report even if there are issues elsewhere in the text). If you're able to, please raise an issue in the Moodle tracker with an example content that breaks for you and/or replication instructions. Then I added an MS Word created table (3 rows, 4 columns, no data, no captions or column headers, 2 cells merged), and got a whole bunch of information. The Moodle Docs may need clarification on 'tables created with applications such as MS Word or similar'. Unfortunately content from applications like Word is typically full of rubbish content which is very hard to clear. We are constantly trying to improve this. Text contrast issues work as expected, but then one expects a user to mess up the text in an application such as MS Word (or know HTML), since text color isn't an option (yet) in Tiny 6. I'm not sure I understand this question? Best wishes, Andrew

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: TinyMCE 6 in Moodle 4.1.4
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andrew, Thanks for your elaborate explanations. As I understand it, the tiny_link plugin is there so one can access the 'Browse repositories' bit that is also there in ATTO (and everything that comes with it). Am I correct? On Autosave If you just refresh the page, then you will get both the form change detetion, and the editor autosave. I tested this, and found the following: When the editor is empty and you start writing, then refresh the page or close the tab/browser, the draft stage is restored once you return to it. For an editor instance that already contained text (let's say you wanted to continue writing a chapter or a paragraph), this process of refreshing / closing the tab and then returning to it causes an exception: 'tiny_autosave/id_page: Skipping draft restoration. The editor is not empty'. On accessibility and images The image without ALT text or role="presentation" issue is maybe a luxury: this type of issues would only get noticed if the text containing them was created way before Moodle implemented WCAG / Accessibility solutions, or if the text was edited -> copied -> pasted outside of Moodle, for instance using MS Word (or similar) or direct HTML editing. I understand that's correct behaviour, but it seems a bit easy to accept images with alt="" and role="presentation" as being accessible. Not all images in text are decorative by default. Tracker issues created Regarding the long text and headings finding: I created a tracker issue: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-78985 Regarding the issue I found about the tables, I also created a tracker issue: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-78986 . I don't think this is so much a bug, but more of a potential improvement to the editor. And some remarks The last two bits of my previous post were more remarks than questions, to be honest: Moodle and the available text editors have made it virtually impossible to create unaccessible content. The only way to create low contrast text, or messed up tables, is when a user does so using a desktop publishing app such as MS Word or similar. I agree with you that Microsoft adds more rubbish to text than anyone can clean up. That's exactly why we recommend our content creators and faculty to write directly in Moodle, or use the 'paste as text' option.

ResponsesInList.Title: HOWTO enable Spell Check in Windows
ResponsesInList.Text: HTML Editor HOWTO enable Spell Check in Windows (and UNIX ). In Moodle 1.4 1. Install aspell in your system. You can download it from http://aspell.net/win32/ 2. Install the dictionaries that you need. (en, es, ca, fr, it etc) 3. Locate the aspell.exe file. P. E "C:\Archivos de programa\Aspell\bin\aspell.exe" 4. Edit the config.php file in your moodle installation directory.  Add the following line $CFG->aspellpath='"C:\Archivos de programa\Aspell\bin\aspell.exe"'; Note the double quotes, its important to keep them to locate the aspell.exe in windows. 5. Now login in your moodle site as admin. Go to HTML Editor settings in the configuration page and set to "YES" the editorSpelling property. Troubleshoting. ------------------ A very odd thing happens with IE caching. Sometimes its necessary to flush the IE cache to be able to see the [ABC] button

ResponsesInList.Title: Best practise (assessability) for use with TinyMCE
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have been asked to enable the TinyMCE editor for our Moodle site. I think the editor is great and really powerful for my teacher's. However i am a bit concerned as to the use of new background colours, and their application within courses as my Teachers are not technical, therefore their understanding of design, UX and accessibility is very low. I know there is an accessibility checker (perfect!) but i don't want to end up with courses pink text on red background any ideas? Kind Regards, Leticia

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Best practise (assessability) for use with TinyMCE
ResponsesInList.Text: That is an issue, even for experienced writers occasionally. Best bet is to educate your teachers. Show them what you do not want them to do. 1. Create a presentation that has examples of what you do not want to see 2. Convert the presentation to a video, e.g new versions of PowerPoint can convert presentations to a wmv file. 3. If needed Convert wmv file to mp4 and put it into the Moodle - Handbrake will easily convert most formats. 5. Make your presentation at a staff meeting, so everyone gets the message, and your mp4 file is uploaded to a Staff only course on what to do, how to use the new editor. 6. Trust your teachers to mostly get it right, and those few who get it wrong, well, they can be reeducated but it can take a few tries. Colour is always an issue, so talk about the colour wheel, and talk about opposites offering high contrast, which is what text should always be. Too  much colour overwhelms the message Too little colour makes it boring and detracts from the message So the message is keep colours to a minimum, but keep them simple. One issue that is a lot more common than we think is background colour. If background colour is too light there is a risk of luminosity overwhelming the text and the message is lost. Some younger people are subject to serious problems with Irlen's Syndrome where luminosity is preventing them of following the text. They need a muted pastel colour, a blue often works, but a pastel green can be ok too, with very dark text, black on green or navy on pastel blue, not red on green. In Oz, it is an unsettling truth that many Aboriginals have Irlen's and it is rarely diagnosed adequately. It is actually even more common amongst Middle Eastern peoples I have been told. Is also not that uncommon in European and Asian populations either. It is similar to dyslexia, but can have a much deeper impact and the two are often confused. Colour blindness too is an issue, so red on green and green on red should always be avoided. Be careful of the "signal colours". Red, yellow and green. Reds and yellows are warning colours, so should really be avoided, muted or pastel greens can be useful in large blocks, are are better used for highlighting a line of text to draw attention to it: Greens can be used to attract attention to important notes but green text needs to be bold otherwise it is lost on this background. Brick colour, not red, can also be used to attract attention to a critical point. Again, it has to be in bold to avoid being overwhelmed by the luminosity of the background. Try these things in a word processing document, see what works what doesn't then use that to build your presentation. Good luck

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Best practise (assessability) for use with TinyMCE
ResponsesInList.Text: While you might find a way to prevent ... why not appeal to teachers understanding that color does affect learning and as educators they should 'sacrifice' their preferences for colors and consider the students. https://elearningindustry.com/4-tips-use-color-in-elearning Is but one reference ... one could probably find some 'brain research' addressing color on the net somewhere as well. Got a training course for your teachers?   Create a course for them to take and choose, on purpose, the most awfull color cominbations you can imagine ... ie, make it hard to read and distracts. 2 cent opinion ... True story  ... I once worked in summers painting classrooms.  The supervisor of the painting crews dropped off appropriate latex for walls and semi-gloss for trim + a direction to paint room #.  Room # was on the East side of the building ... morning sun ... and the building itself was constructed in the 1920's ... classroom on second floor and had very tall bay windows which required painters to use a ladder to paint the walls/window trim on that side of the classroom. Teacher in that room had been very critical of many things on the campus including things like facilities, AC (of which there was none - Texas), drab color of classrooms, etc. The color we were to use (had to use) ... lime green.  My painting partner and I both asked the supervisor if he was sure!!!   Supervisor who was to retired at the close of summer smiled and said 'Yep!' I didn't teach on that campus, but heard from other teachers I knew on that campus how much trouble the teacher in Room # had that year with discipline of students. Go figure! :\ 'spirit of sharing', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML/PHP
ResponsesInList.Text: mm I think we should take a step back here and ask what exactly do you want to do? You do not need to know any HTML, PLP or MySQL skills to use Moodle, a good understanding of how to explore a new product is essential though. If you want to create courses and classes , then you can just use Moodle without any HTML or PHP or My SQL . As long as you have an idea, then you can create a course, edit and add resources you want to use in lessons to it, add in images, add in such things as Wikis, pdf files, links to other web sites, make documents online, for students to use online, there is a lot you can do. If you want to do things with the screen, like add in things that Moodle does not currently have, like change the layout you want to use, then PHP, HTML and CSS on their own will not help you too much at the beginning. If this is what you are after, then you need to start with themes. You best start here , which should give you an idea of where to go to next. You might want to create new blocks, new activities . These will take some time and planning and a really good understanding of what Moodle is and how to use it. Once you get used to it, using Moodle is actually easy, and the learning curve does not need to be too steep.

ResponsesInList.Text:
At the moment I'm working on developing a theme based on Boost for Moodle v3.4, and I'm also trying to figure out a standard way to change the icons for some of the Atto buttons. In non-boost themes, we could do this just by adding the new icons in the pix_plugins folder in the theme. In boost-based themes, using fontawesome icon system, things are a bit different. In atto plugins that add the button as (ie, using image icons): 
```text
this.addButton({


    icon: 'icon',


    iconComponent: 'atto_designelements'


    callback: this._displayDialogue


});
```
 These can be overridden in the theme by adding the new icons in the pix_plugins folder or defining the icon map in a class that extends the \core\output\icon_system_fontawesome class. See Essential theme for how its done. In the icon map you could do something like the following to change the button icon: 
```text
$iconmap['
atto_designelements:icon
'] = 'fa-font';
```
 However, some atto plugins already use the fontawesome icons for their buttons and these can be overridden in the theme icon map, but not via the pix_plugins method. But the problem I face is that it is not consistent (at least thats what I found). Some atto plugins use the core icon set, eg: 
```text
this.addBasicButton({


      exec: 'removeFormat',


      icon: 'e/clear_formatting'


});
```
 In such cases, we have to do 
```text
$iconmap['
core:
e/clear_formatting
'] = 'fa-eraser';
```
 to update the Atto button icon but this also updates the core icon as well. The following does not work. Or am I doing something wrong??? 
```text
$iconmap['
atto_clear:icon
'] = 'fa-eraser';
```
 So it becomes quite a laborious task to override atto icons, as you have to first find out which icon is used and this information is buried in several layers of folders. If there is an easier way then I would surely like to know that. Thanks, ... Rajneel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Possible to change font size of equations?
ResponsesInList.Text: Current font size list that works for me using MathJax and the Atto Equation Editor. \tiny{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \tiny{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \) \scriptsize{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \scriptsize{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \) \small{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \small{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \) \normalsize{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \normalsize{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \) \large{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \large{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \) \Large{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \Large{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \) \LARGE{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \LARGE{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \) \huge{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \huge{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \) \Huge{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} gives this: \( \Huge{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVXYZ} \)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Possible to change font size of equations?
ResponsesInList.Text:
You can change the default scale of MathJax in mathJax configuration (either in MathJax filter configuration or in Addditional HTML - depending on your version of moodle) For example add under MathJax.Hub.Config({

   "HTML-CSS": {scale: 95}, to make it a little smaller than default 100 scale. If your site is using SVG output check http://docs.mathjax.org/en/latest/options/SVG.html You can use old (La)TeX commands to change "font size" like AL suggested but you can in fact use any font size in html around MathJax code to resize it - Mathjax takes font size from surrounding html tags. See demo in http://www.mathjax.org/demos/scaling-math/ The only problem is that Atto does not have font scaling option in editor toolbar. For example

Test 500% \( \alpha \beta \gamma \)

gives Test 500% \( \alpha \beta \gamma \)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Possible to change font size of equations?
ResponsesInList.Text: Andrew, Are you using MathJax or the TeX notation filter to render the mathematics?  MathJax normally adjusts to the correct text size.  The TeX filter produces GIF or PNG images that do not match as closely. If the TeX and Imagemagick binaries are missing on the system, the TeX filter uses an included mimetex binary.  Mimetex usually appears much larger than the surrounding TeX.

ResponsesInList.Title: Shortcodes (Wordpress Style)
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello All, I wondered if anyone has ever looked at the possibility of adding support for shortcodes the way some Wordpress themes do. The better Wordpress themes add an icon to the WYSIWYG editor that gives users a menu of available codes. These can be used to insert an array of different elements like message boxes, buttons, column layouts, accordions, toggles, image backgrounds and styles. Here are two examples: http://themes.truethemes.net/Karma/features/shortcodes-demo http://dreamthemedesign.com/themes/u-design/features/shortcodes/ When a user selects a short code style from the menu the code is embedded into the editor which typically looks something like this (for a message box): `[message type=` `"info"` `]Your message goes here... [/message]` The user then replaces "Your message goes here...." with the actual message they want to display. This shields users from the complexity of the underlying css and makes editing much easier. For this to happen in Moodle I think it would require three things: A tinymce pluign to add the icon / drop down picker for styles Filters to replace the short code with the required html (js calls) Styles (js) in the theme Would that be the case or is there a better way to do it? Also, can Moodle handle filters which do more complex replacements like this one for an Accordion which has two elements for the title and the conent: 
```text
[toggle_content title="Toggle Content Title..."]
Your content goes here...
[/toggle_content]
```
 Although I have mentioned javascript / accordions above I was really only hoping to be able to do something with simpler elements like buttons, message boxes, image backgrounds. Any thoughts on this would be greatly appreciated. Thanks, Jez

ResponsesInList.Text: I've thought about doing this to let people take advantage of some of the more advanced bits of Bootstrap (particularly the javascript: http://twitter.github.io/bootstrap/javascript.html ). It should work pretty much as you say. I think you could (sometimes) skip a step though and just get TinyMCE to insert the correct HTML in the first place. This would then have the correct visual look even while editing. See here http://www.tinymce.com/wiki.php/Configuration:style_formats and here for a demo: http://www.tinymce.com/tryit/custom_formats.php

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deprecated tags
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to encourage the abolishment of deprecated tags like FONT.  The same effect can be exactly achieved by using the SPAN tag.  Wouldn't it be a (relatively) simple thing to change the HTMLArea code to use SPAN in place of FONT? On a related, but more style-based issue, the use of outdated HTML parameters and their values in HTML tags should be replaced with the CSS STYLE parameter.  This is a bit trickier, but should be implemented to preserve standards compatibility. Thanks, Ammon

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deprecated tags
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ammon... I go along with a part of what you said. <FONT> is deprecated for some good reasons, in favour of CSS controls.  But CSS isn't a "related issue", it's the same issue... the only means of replacing <FONT> with <SPAN> or <DIV> is by using them to embed or refer to CSS controls. What is more, the biggest gain for replacing <FONT> with CSS controls is to liberate a page from its formatting, thus allowing a page or a whole site to take on almost any appearance by swapping or modifying a stylesheet.  That worthy objective isn't achieved by moving the effects applied by the <FONT> tag into the Style attribute of a <SPAN> / <DIV> tag.  Rather the <SPAN> / <DIV> tag must be given a Class and/or ID which is referenced in an external stylesheet. Little is ever cut and dry, however.  CSS controls are often not read by mobile devices which will happily read a <FONT> tag.  Ultimately all formatting, from the layout of a page to the borders around a table should be under the control of a stylesheet; but "preserve standards compatibility" is a slightly dangerous phrase, since the CSS controls are often less cross-browser compliant than the alternative HTML controls. In fact, Petrik, taking full advantage of styles in the HTML editor is not an easy business, because it should mean that the editor reads all the styles from CSS files and embedded within the <HEAD> section of the document, puts them into a drop-down menu of the editor for selection, and somehow applies them faithfully within the editor WYSIWYG view.  At the end of the day, <FONT> is deprecated, but I doubt it's going to exit stage left and leave us in the lurch any time soon. Best regards - Andi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: "A draft version of this text was automatically restored" Huh?
ResponsesInList.Text: The autosave is a feature of Atto that I believe was added in 2.8. It saves a draft copy based on context after the interval defined in the settings. If the browser window is closed prematurely, this copy is reloaded in the next page the user opens with the same context.  If the page is saved or cancelled with a button at the page bottom, the draft copies for that context are deleted so that there is a blank editor the next time. I have not notice the problem with editing questions, but I suspect that it is because the user  instead of saving is using the button "Save and continue editing" then checks the preview, and closes the window instead of saving the question again. This may also be a new feature. I just noticed it recently. You might encourage the save with the other button. Otherwise, a unwanted draft file can be removed from the editor with ctl-z or the undo button.

ResponsesInList.Title: Using Firefox with moodle on OS-X & Windows to display buttons in HTMLarea
ResponsesInList.Text: I have just realised that Firefox is the only browser for Mac OS-X that will display the buttons in HTMLArea. The achilles heel for Firefox is the nannying way that it won't allow pasting into HTMLArea by default (something to do with Javascript security apparently). So I have uploaded a user.js file that should function both for OS-X & Windows users. Assuming that you have already installed or upgraded to Firefox 0.9x (.92 or .93): on OS-X save to folder: Library : Application Support : Firefox : profiles : default.xxx on Windows (2000 or XP), save to folder: c:\Documents and Settings\%USERNAME%\Application Data\Mozilla\Firefox\profiles\default.xxx\ where %USERNAME% is the username what you logged in as (you did log in to Win XP now didn't you?)

ResponsesInList.Title: Tinymce madness
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi people, I'm trying to use the tinymce editor as part of a project I'm working on, but it appears that tinymce converts things like apostrophes to '. This is causing problems for me because they're inserted into the database that way (html2text doesn't seem to catch it) and then when forum posts are emailed in plain text form the ' appears in the mail. Has anyone encountered this problem before, or know of a fix?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tinymce madness
ResponsesInList.Text: html2text is supposed to catch these things so it's more likely a problem with that rather than TinyMCE. It would be interesting to test if catches &#039 i.e. effectively identical but textually different from &#39 because (I think) that's what PHP generates going the other way.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tinymce madness
ResponsesInList.Text: PHP generates different things depending on phase of the moon as far as I can tell... see the docs for get_html_translation_table() . In any event, html2text does NOT convert these, or indeed any of the other ones that are possible (such as for "curly quotes" or emdash). I'm going to try to configure tinymce to not do any conversions, and failing that I might have to convert the entities to their actual unicode characters before inserting into the database.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tinymce madness
ResponsesInList.Text: I found a solution to this problem. Tinymce maintains a list of characters it will convert, and you can override it: entities : "60,lt,62,gt,38,amp,34,quot" Doing that means only those entities are changed, and the other characters are stored in their unicode forms.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tinymce general question at category level in moodle 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello Tom,

Your problem isn't actually anything to do with the editor - certain 'pages' in Moodle (those that are actually constructs of many elements pulled together) like category and home pages won't accept many things. Not only do they not like hotspots many table properties are accepted either.

You can only get round this (in my experience - others may have other solutions) by 'breaking' the page (editing the php code) or using flash or something similar. We have used both, but I'm no php programmer and someone did that for me. If no one else can help you with that perhaps I can get a colleague to explain, but you'd need to be confident in changing code. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tinymce general question at category level in moodle 1.9

Click on a icon to go to a category page - I created the clickable info and scrolling images there in flash, although we've also kept the normal course links. We've not used this technique to condense info/avoid scroll, rather to enhance the quality and look of the information - but it could easily be there for that purpose. Do you or a colleague have access to flash and can create a swf file menu? If so, you can simply add a swf via an iFrame (I can give you the code - v simple). Also, animated gifs can go in here. A table in a category or front page should (if I remember correctly - been a while since I tried) take an image, which you can add a URL link to within the TINYMCE editor (rather than importing an image map) but it won't do things like support background colour or Javascript in these pages. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: removing embedded video / code from a Moodle page
ResponsesInList.Text:
Happens frequently. Good news is you don't really need the edit button to access the edit screen. You just need to find out the correct url for this edit screen. Maybe it is possible to access the edit screen for section summaries directly by entering the correct url into the location bar of your browser. That means you haven't lost the ability to edit the summary, just the link to click on to get to the edit screen. If there is a section summary on your site where the edit icon is still showing, you can copy the link location of that edit icon. (Right click mouse and choose: copy link location) Paste this in the location bar of your browser. It should look something like this: 
```text
http://www.yoursite.com/moodle/course/editsection.php?id=295
```
 Now, if you replace that last number, you can use this link to update other section summaries. Problem is how to find out which number your section has. If it is a recent mistake, maybe your browser's history still shows all the links you visited. Maybe you can find out which one it is this way with a little trial and error. Other way is directly editing the database . Tell us if you have phpmyadmin (a tool to directly access the database, take a look at the download page )? Here are different solutions.

ResponsesInList.Title: TinyMCE key event logger plugin
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! I'm actively developing a plugin for Moodle using TinyMCE which captures key event data. Our first release has been submitted to the plugin repository: https://moodle.org/plugins/tiny_keylogger (pending review as of 5/24/23 with an estimated 130-day wait). The plugin captures and formats the data into a downloadable JSON file format available to editing teachers and the administrator with the right URL . The files are structured, user ID obfuscated, UNIX time-stamped streams from the writing process. The file format is compatible with a separate service we've created, so far with this data we have created ML which can verify the authorship of a single student across time (e.g. we can verify that the student remains the author accessing the online text area over time and across submissions) calculating the time and effort of the writing process, calculate editing %, character counts, writing efficiency estimate the amount of text that was entered via copy/paste provide guidance on the amount of text injected via AI extension (such as Grammarly and Google's autocomplete While the calculations are offline currently, we're developing this service further to connect the ML via API. If you're interested in learning more while we wait for the plugin review, let me know (code is also posted here: https://github.com/cursiveinc/moodle-tinymce_keylogger -Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: How to desactivate right click in tinyMCE?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I work with tinyMCE 3.5.1.1 on Moodle 2.3.2 and I would like to know haw to desactivate the plugin of right click in the tinymce window. It send me an error message when I want to cut/copy/paste something and says that it si not compatible with the browser ( Firefox , Chrome or Safari) and that I haver to use the keyboard shortcuts. I'm ok for that but some users do not even know this shortcuts and prefer copy and paste with the right click. Do you have an idea how to desactivate this right click menu of tinymce and have basic right click menu of the system? Thank you for your help. Regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to desactivate right click in tinyMCE?
ResponsesInList.Text: This is in Modle 2.4, it may or may not be the same or similar for your version. From your Moodle directory go to the file /lib/editor/tinymce/lib.php Search for the line:  (single quotes included) 'searchreplace,paste,directionality,fullscreen,nonbreaking,contextmenu,' . delete "contextmenu," (don't forget the comma) so the line now reads: 'searchreplace,paste,directionality,fullscreen,nonbreaking,' . Save it. That should do it. Our Moodle is on an Intranet with no outside Internet access causing the tinyMCE spell checkers to not work. I was very happy when Moodle 2.4 let you turn off spell checking. With it turned off the browser's spell checker would mark the word as bad but if you right clicked you got the tinyMCE menu. You could CTRL and right click but that's not intuitive. Hope this helps. PS: be sure that line still ends with a period character after the single quote. That's the concatenate character in php. (kinda like a + sign for strings)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to desactivate right click in tinyMCE?
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes! Thank you very much for your help, it works!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to desactivate right click in tinyMCE?
ResponsesInList.Text: Note, in more recent versions of Moodle, you may be able to do this using the "Custom configuration" option on Admin -> Plugins -> Text editors -> TinyMCE HTML editor -> General settings. However, the only way to know what you can change is probably to look in https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/lib/editor/tinymce/lib.php#L119 , and if you make a mistake here, you can probably break the editor completely. To change take out the context menu, you probably need {" plugins" => " lists,table,style,layer,advhr,advlink,emotions,inlinepopups, searchreplace,paste,directionality,fullscreen,nonbreaking, insertdatetime,save,iespell,preview,print,noneditable,visualchars,xhtmlxtras,template,pagebreak" }

ResponsesInList.Title: How to make TinyMCE Responsive
Re: How to make TinyMCE Responsive
ResponsesInList.Text: You can test such css with Custom Css box in the settings of More theme (in administration menu). If you add there the css from that jsFiddle example table.mceLayout, textarea.tinyMCE { width: 100% !important; } .mceToolbar td { display:table-row; float: left; } .mceToolbar td:nth-of-type(11){ clear: left; } toolbars get wrapped (responsive) according to screen width but it's not very ideal solution because you get easily a long row of buttons that fill small screen phones... You can see the effect better in previous versions of moodle like moodle 2.5 with for example Essential theme (and smaller buttons in tinymce toolbar/old o2k7 skin) That css wraps toolbar rows if screen (window) width is less than 600px and keeps the toolbars at 600px if screen (window) width is more than 600px. I think core moodle developers did implement some wrapping already (wrap plugin?) to tinymce before they started to develop Atto (default editor of moodle 2.7) but nobody tried to create actual responsive skins or mobile themes for tinymce since core moodle developers decided to drop support for working with tinymce.

ResponsesInList.Title: HTML editor : how to order and to add icons ?
ResponsesInList.Text: hi How can I add icons to HTML editor and change their order ? Thanks Piero

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML editor : how to order and to add icons ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Piero, Changing the icon order is easy. Adding one is also easy, IF it is for a tool that has just been left off, such as 'Justify.' Adding a tool icon for something entirely new to the editor, such as Nanogong, is another matter entirely as you have to create the whole plugin from scratch. Read through the documentation for that. Since you did not say which Moodle editor you have, this is how you would add or re-order icons for my Moodle 2.3.1+. Open the file yourmoodle/lib/editor/tinymce/lib.php and look at lines 146 and 147. They define row one of the tools. Notice it is simple list of tool names seperated by commas and vertical bars for grouping . 146 'theme_advanced_buttons1' => "{$fontbutton}fontsizeselect,formatselect", 147 'theme_advanced_buttons1_add' => "|,undo,redo,|,search,replace,|,fullscreen", Lines 148 and 149 define the second row of tools. In line 148, right after the word justifyright, if you add a comma and the word justifyfull, you will add the missing Justify toolbutton. (If you try this, don't foget to reload your browser to make it update and show the new tool button.) 148 'theme_advanced_buttons2' => "bold,italic,underline,strikethrough,sub,sup,|,justifyleft,justifycenter,justifyright, justifyfull ", 149 'theme_advanced_buttons2_add' => "|,cleanup,removeformat,pastetext,pasteword,|,forecolor,backcolor,|,ltr,rtl", Lines 150 and 151 define the third row of tools. (I left them out.) To change the order of tools, just change the order of the tool names listed in those lines. Be careful as if you forget a comma or do the _add incorrectly, your tools may not show up. Of course it would be best if you made a backup copy of the file first...just in case. Visit http://www.tinymce.com/tryit/full.php and you can see other missing tools to try out. Hope this helps, AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Prevent storing http:// in urls?
ResponsesInList.Text: When in the editor, if I put in a HTML like this: After it's saved, it is stored like this: (http://moodle25 being my local dev box) Is there a way to prevent this behaviour?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Prevent storing http:// in urls?
ResponsesInList.Text: There isn't. Why do you want to prevent this behaviour?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Prevent storing http:// in urls?
ResponsesInList.Text: Short and to the point... Basically, I understand there are three reasons for you to not do what you want to do. Specificity, backup/restore and Moodle's image handling and storage security. There may be other reasons and/or what I am suggesting is not accurate, but it is a perception. Consider if you have 250 courses. This has to be a lot of images. You may have the same image name in three or four different courses, but they may not be the same image. Relative referencing will seek to use images in the cache first, which may not be the same image as the course you are using requires. The page resides in one folder and images are stored in a completely separate folder which may not have a close relationship with the actual course folder. With backup/restore, where does the image reside within the Moodle? In v1.9 it would reside in the moodledata folder under the name of the course and in the image's name. This was not very secure so in v2.x, it was that images would be stored in folders, under an alias. The alias name would be stored in a relevant field within the database . Backups would use the real name of the file, according to the database entry. On restoration, a new alias is assigned, (I think). Without the absolute path, this would be an impossible situation to manage. Security is enhanced and backups and restorations are more accurate. I hope this outlines some of the issues inherent in Tim's statement.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Prevent storing http:// in urls?
ResponsesInList.Text: Context , usually. So if my site is running http and I'm referencing shared files outside the moodle folder (on the intranet for instance) then we move the server to https then I don't have to use the /admin/tools/replace/ to fudge all the links, because I wouldn't have to. I also regular move data between my servers - backup mostly, but also database clones. Again, I have to blat all the links using the replace tool every time because - aha - they are absolutely referenced with the site url. I wouldn't have to do that step if they had been relatively [but still root] referenced. Just an administrative step, yes. It also adds an extra step to some of the javascript plugins I write that parse urls in the page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Prevent storing http:// in urls?
ResponsesInList.Text: From some quick testing, it appears this may not possible due to Moodle and web browser design and security. ResponsesInList.Title: Problem : HTMLArea popups do not send HTTP headers with character encoding
ResponsesInList.Text: After having looked at the code, I found that popups launched from a HTMLArea editor (e.g. to insert an image) only send the encoding in a meta tag , and not in a HTTP header. Now our Moodle site is in UTF-8. Since our web server by default sends an ISO-8859-1 encoding header for all pages, foreign characters in the popups appear garbled, as the HTTP header encoding overrides the one specified in the meta-tag (UTF-8) (note that this is the correct behavior, according to section 5.2.2 of the HTML 4.01 specification ). This problem doesn't occur with other Moodle pages, since they all send a raw HTTP header with the correct character encoding. Can this be considered a bug ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: text editor not showing or not complete
ResponsesInList.Text: The default editor has been changed from TinyMCE to Atto in 2.7.  You may change your editor to TinyMCE in the profile panel, rather than default HTML editor.  This will give you nearly the same editor you had in 2.6. However, change of fonts and sizes is deliberately not part of Atto for some good reasons.  Changing formatting in this way is difficult for screen readers to interpret and may not be portable across themes and platforms.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: text editor not showing or not complete
ResponsesInList.Text: There are several options: You can define your own styles that then be available in the paragraph styles drop down You could write a plugin for Atto that provides font and size options You could apply the required changes in the HTML itself
